text: who's got that list of all the failed efforts to make python fast with a graveyard of compilers?

elements.text: who's got that list of all the failed efforts to make python fast with a graveyard of compilers?

text: Depending on how you define ‘failed’, I don’t think many of them have done so. I don’t know of many that are no longer actively developed or don’t have users

elements.text: Depending on how you define ‘failed’, I don’t think many of them have done so. I don’t know of many that are no longer actively developed or don’t have users

text: Fair enough - there was a pretty hefty list of projects that just fell by the wayside that someone here posted a while ago.

elements.text: Fair enough - there was a pretty hefty list of projects that just fell by the wayside that someone here posted a while ago.

text: I really like cython though. Its still widely used.

text: But then again are you really coding with python at that point :grin:

elements.text: But then again are you really coding with python at that point

text: nope. Same story with Numba, "ok so I can't use dictionary and can't use class...what am I writing again?  C?"  (ps: they are actively expanding the subset everyday)

elements.text: nope. Same story with Numba, "ok so I can't use dictionary and can't use class...what am I writing again?  C?"  (ps: they are actively expanding the subset everyday)

text: With Numba at least you don’t have to learn new syntax. There is lots of numerical code you can just slap `@jit` on and see a speed up.

elements.text: With Numba at least you don’t have to learn new syntax. There is lots of numerical code you can just slap
@jit
on and see a speed up.

text: only works for toys though, as real world python uses a lot of foreign subroutine and you can't mix them inside `@jit`

elements.text: only works for toys though, as real world python uses a lot of foreign subroutine and you can't mix them inside
@jit

text: I think saying it ‘only works for toys’ is going way too far, but yes. It (like all of these things) is not a composable solution

elements.text: I think saying it ‘only works for toys’ is going way too far, but yes. It (like all of these things) is not a composable solution

text: right, my bad, I would only use that wording here I guess. But essentially, yes

text: Numba is great for a lot of stuff I do in vision and image processing. Often just arrays are good enough for that.

elements.text: Numba is great for a lot of stuff I do in vision and image processing. Often just arrays are good enough for that.

text: IronPython, based on C#, is quite a good implementation of Python. It is high performance and has .NET’s security. Microsoft was even talking about adding a numeric add-on that produced high performance numerics, ala Julia.

elements.text: IronPython, based on C#, is quite a good implementation of Python. It is high performance and has .NET’s security. Microsoft was even talking about adding a numeric add-on that produced high performance numerics, ala Julia.

text: TIL IronPython, thx. But it seems to not have upgraded to python3?

elements.text: TIL IronPython, thx. But it seems to not have upgraded to python3?

text: Yes, IronPython appears to be another abandoned MS project.
